text: CHAPTER I. OF THE KING OF OAKENREALM, AND HIS WIFE AND HIS CHILD.
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: Of old there was a land which was so much a woodland, that a minstrel
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: thereof said it that a squirrel might go from end to end, and all about,
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: from tree to tree, and never touch the earth: therefore was that land
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: called Oakenrealm.
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: The lord and king thereof was a stark man, and so great a warrior that
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: in his youth he took no delight in aught else save battle and tourneys.
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: But when he was hard on forty years old, he came across a daughter of
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: a certain lord, whom he had vanquished, and his eyes bewrayed him
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: into longing, so that he gave back to the said lord the havings he had
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: conquered of him that he might lay the maiden in his kingly bed. So he
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: brought her home with him to Oakenrealm and wedded her.
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: Tells the tale that he rued not his bargain, but loved her so dearly
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: that for a year round he wore no armour, save when she bade him play in
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: the tilt-yard for her desport and pride.
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: So wore the days till she went with child and was near her time, and
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: then it betid that three kings who marched on Oakenrealm banded them
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: together against him, and his lords and thanes cried out on him to lead
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: them to battle, and it behoved him to do as they would.
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: So he sent out the tokens and bade an hosting at his chief city, and
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: when all was ready he said farewell to his wife and her babe unborn, and
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: went his ways to battle once more: but fierce was his heart against the
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: foemen, that they had dragged him away from his love and his joy.
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: Even amidst of his land he joined battle with the host of the ravagers,
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: and the tale of them is short to tell, for they were as the wheat before
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: the hook. But as he followed up the chase, a mere thrall of the fleers
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: turned on him and cast his spear, and it reached him whereas his hawberk
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: was broken, and stood deep in, so that he fell to earth unmighty: and
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: when his lords and chieftains drew about him, and cunning men strove to
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: heal him, it was of no avail, and he knew that his soul was departing.
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: Then he sent for a priest, and for the Marshal of the host, who was a
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: great lord, and the son of his father's brother, and in few words bade
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: him look to the babe whom his wife bore about, and if it were a man, to
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: cherish him and do him to learn all that a king ought to know; and if it
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: were a maiden, that he should look to her wedding well and worthily: and
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: he let swear him on his sword, on the edges and the hilts, that he would
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: do even so, and be true unto his child if child there were: and he bade
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: him have rule, if so be the lords would, and all the people, till the
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: child were of age to be king: and the Marshal swore, and all the lords
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: who stood around bare witness to his swearing. Thereafter the priest
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: houselled the King, and he received his Creator, and a little while
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: after his soul departed.
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: But the Marshal followed up the fleeing foe, and two battles more he
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: fought before he beat them flat to earth; and then they craved for
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: peace, and he went back to the city in mickle honour.
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: But in the King's city of Oakenham he found but little joy; for both
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: the King was bemoaned, whereas he had been no hard man to his folk; and
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: also, when the tidings and the King's corpse came back to Oakenrealm,
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: his Lady and Queen took sick for sorrow and fear, and fell into labour
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: of her child, and in childing of a man-bairn she died, but the lad
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: lived, and was like to do well.
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: So there was one funeral for the slain King and for her whom his slaying
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: had slain: and when that was done, the little king was borne to the
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: font, and at his christening he gat to name Christopher.
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: Thereafter the Marshal summoned all them that were due thereto to come
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: and give homage to the new king, and even so did they, though he were
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: but a babe, yea, and who had but just now been a king lying in his
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: mother's womb. But when the homage was done, then the Marshal called
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: together the wise men, and told them how the King that was had given him
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: in charge his son as then unborn, and the ruling of the realm till the
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: said son were come to man's estate: but he bade them seek one worthier
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: if they had heart to gainsay the word of their dying lord. Then all they
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: said that he was worthy and mighty and the choice of their dear lord,
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: and that they would have none but he.
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: So then was the great folk-mote called, and the same matter was laid
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: before all the people, and none said aught against it, whereas no man
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: was ready to name another to that charge and rule, even had it been his
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: own self.
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: Now then by law was the Marshal, who hight Rolf, lord and earl of the
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: land of Oakenrealm. He ruled well and strongly, and was a fell warrior:
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: he was well befriended by many of the great; and the rest of them feared
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: him and his friends: as for the commonalty, they saw that he held the
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: realm in peace; and for the rest, they knew little and saw less of him,
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: and they paid to his bailiffs and sheriffs as little as they could, and
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: more than they would. But whereas that left them somewhat to grind their
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: teeth on, and they were not harried, they were not so ill content. So
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: the Marshal throve, and lacked nothing of a king's place save the bare
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: name.

author: Morris, William

text: CHAPTER II. OF THE KING'S SON.
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: As for the King's son, to whom the folk had of late done homage as king,
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: he was at first seen about a corner of the High House with his nurses;
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: and then in a while it was said, and the tale noted, but not much, that
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: he must needs go for his health's sake, and because he was puny, to some
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: stead amongst the fields, and folk heard say that he was gone to the
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: strong house of a knight somewhat stricken in years, who was called Lord
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: Richard the Lean. The said house was some twelve miles from Oakenham,
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: not far from the northern edge of the wild-wood. But in a while, scarce
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: more than a year, Lord Richard brake up house at the said castle, and
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: went southward through the forest. Of this departure was little said,
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: for he was not a man amongst the foremost. As for the King's little son,
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: if any remembered that he was in the hands of the said Lord Richard,
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: none said aught about it; for if any thought of the little babe at all,
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: they said to themselves, Never will he come to be king.
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: Now as for Lord Richard the Lean, he went far through the wood, and
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: until he was come to another house of his, that stood in a clearing
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: somewhat near to where Oakenrealm marched on another country, which
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: hight Meadham; though the said wild-wood ended not where Oakenrealm
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: ended, but stretched a good way into Meadham; and betwixt one and the
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: other much rough country there was.
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: It is to be said that amongst those who went to this stronghold of the
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: woods was the little King Christopher, no longer puny, but a stout
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: babe enough: so he was borne amongst the serving men and thralls to
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: the castle of the Outer March; and he was in no wise treated as a great
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: man's son; but there was more than one woman who was kind to him, and
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: as he waxed in strength and beauty month by month, both carle and
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: quean fell to noting him, and, for as little as he was, he began to be
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: well-beloved.
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: As to the stead where he was nourished, though it were far away amongst
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: the woods, it was no such lonely or savage place: besides the castle and
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: the houses of it, there was a merry thorpe in the clearing, the houses
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: whereof were set down by the side of a clear and pleasant little stream.
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: Moreover the goodmen and swains of the said township were no ill folk,
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: but bold of heart, free of speech, and goodly of favour; and the women
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: of them fair, kind, and trusty. Whiles came folk journeying in to
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: Oakenrealm or out to Meadham, and of these some were minstrels, who had
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: with them tidings of what was astir whereas folk were thicker in the
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: world, and some chapmen, who chaffered with the thorpe-dwellers, and
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: took of them the woodland spoil for such outland goods as those woodmen
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: needed.
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: So wore the years, and in Oakenham King Christopher was well nigh
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: forgotten, and in the wild-wood had never been known clearly for King's
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: son. At first, by command of Rolf the Marshal, a messenger came
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: every year from Lord Richard with a letter that told of how the lad
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: Christopher did. But when five years were worn, the Marshal bade send
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: him tidings thereof every three years; and by then it was come to the
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: twelfth year, and still the tidings were that the lad throve ever, and
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: meanwhile the Marshal sat fast in his seat with none to gainsay, the
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: word went to Lord Richard that he should send no more, for that he, the
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: Marshal, had heard enough of the boy; and if he throve it were well, and
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: if not, it was no worse. So wore the days and the years.

text: CHAPTER III. OF THE KING OF MEADHAM AND HIS DAUGHTER.
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: Tells the tale that in the country which lay south of Oakenrealm, and
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: was called Meadham, there was in these days a king whose wife was dead,
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: but had left him a fair daughter, who was born some four years after
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: King Christopher. A good man was this King Roland, mild, bounteous, and
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: no regarder of persons in his justice; and well-beloved he was of his
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: folk: yet could not their love keep him alive; for, whenas his daughter
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: was of the age of twelve years, he sickened unto death; and so, when he
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: knew that his end drew near, he sent for the wisest of his wise men,
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: and they came unto him sorrowing in the High House of his chiefest city,
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: which hight Meadhamstead. So he bade them sit down nigh unto his bed,
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: and took up the word and spake:
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: "Masters, and my good lords, ye may see clearly that a sundering is at
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: hand, and that I must needs make a long journey, whence I shall come
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: back never; now I would, and am verily of duty bound thereto, that I
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: leave behind me some good order in the land. Furthermore, I would that
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: my daughter, when she is of age thereto, should be Queen in Meadham, and
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: rule the land; neither will it be many years before she shall be of ripe
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: age for ruling, if ever she may be; and I deem not that there shall be
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: any lack in her, whereas her mother could all courtesy, and was as wise
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: as a woman may be. But how say ye, my masters?"
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: So they all with one consent said Yea, and they would ask for no better
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: king than their lady his daughter. Then said the King:
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: "Hearken carefully, for my time is short: Yet is she young and a maiden,
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: though she be wise. Now therefore do I need some man well looked to of
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: the folk, who shall rule the land in her name till she be of eighteen
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: winters, and who shall be her good friend and counsellor into all wisdom
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: thereafter. Which of you, my masters, is meet for this matter?"
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: Then they all looked one on the other, and spake not. And the King said:
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: "Speak, some one of you, without fear; this is no time for tarrying."
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: Thereon spake an elder, the oldest of them, and said: "Lord, this is
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: the very truth, that none of us here present are meet for this office:
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: whereas, among other matters, we be all unmeet for battle; some of us
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: have never been warriors, and other some are past the age for leading an
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: host. To say the sooth, King, there is but one man in Meadham who may do
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: what thou wilt, and not fail; both for his wisdom, and his might afield,
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: and the account which is had of him amongst the people; and that man is
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: Earl Geoffrey, of the Southern Marches."
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: "Ye say sooth," quoth the King; "but is he down in the South, or nigher
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: to hand?"
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: Said the elder: "He is as now in Meadhamstead, and may be in this
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: chamber in scant half an hour." So the King bade send for him, and there
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: was silence in the chamber till he came in, clad in a scarlet kirtle and
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: a white cloak, and with his sword by his side. He was a tall man,
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: bigly made; somewhat pale of face, black and curly of hair; blue-eyed,
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: thin-lipped, and hook-nosed as an eagle; a man warrior-like, and
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: somewhat fierce of aspect. He knelt down by the King's bedside, and
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: asked him in a sorrowful voice what he would, and the King said: "I ask
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: a great matter of thee, and all these my wise men, and I myself,
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: withal, deem that thou canst do it, and thou alone--nay, hearken: I am
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: departing, and I would have thee hold my place, and do unto my people
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: even what I would do if I myself were living; and to my daughter as
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: nigh to that as may be. I say all this thou mayst do, if thou wilt be as
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: trusty and leal to me after I am dead, as thou hast seemed to all men's
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
author: Morris, William

text: eyes to have been while I was living. What sayest thou?"
title: Child Christopher and Goldilind the Fair
